file_content.text: Unfortunately, a situation has developed in the Senate. A hearing, to investigate Special Forces' recent activities. You've been called to testify.
I'll head back to Coruscant immediately.
Understood.
Good. I'll give you a full briefing once you arrive. Garza out.
Why is the Senate suddenly interested in our activities again?
What's this about?
The situation is complicated. I'll tell you more when you arrive. Garza out.
I've spent more than enough time with Senators, General.
Not the Senate again.
Participation is not optional.
Hurry back to Coruscant so we can get this over with. I'll give you more details when you arrive. Garza out.
Hello, Major. Our troops are already back on the move--more than one senior general is singing our praises at the moment.
This is in sharp contrast to the numerous complaints I received from Senator Evran over the course of your mission.
I'm no fan of Evran, but I wish you had done more to keep him satisfied. Our work is not done in a vacuum.
I'll try to play nicer in the future, General.
My apologies.
I'd rather you succeed than play nice, but it couldn't hurt.
Nothing I did would've made Evran happy.
He was impossible to please.
I'm sure something could've been done to make him less angry, at least.
We're at war. Bureaucrats aren't my first priority.
I don't play politics.
Of course not. But ignoring men like Evran isn't an option.
I also received a handful of written complaints from Senator Evran during your mission. Nothing unexpected from a man like him. You've done well.
I worked hard to balance our needs with Evran's demands.
Thank you.
Your work paid off.
The op ended up being a lot rougher than I expected.
I'm just glad it's over.
Any challenges were well worth it.
That moron would've cost us the war.
Evran was a fool.
Possibly, but cooler heads prevailed.
Possibly even more impressive, Senator Evran's staff sent me a very complimentary message regarding your conduct. Apparently you made a good impression.
I'm glad I was able to represent us well.
That's good to hear.
Yes, and that's always very helpful in times like these.
No surprise there.
I played nice to get our troops. Nothing more.
I couldn't care less.
That's all that was needed.
With more manpower on the ground to supplement our space forces, the tide of this campaign will finally turn in our favor.
We're only a few steps away from General Rakton himself. He'll have to commit his personal forces somewhere soon. When he does, you'll be there to strike.
When we get our shot at Rakton, I'll be ready.
Count me in.
I'm glad to hear it.
I can't wait to finally meet Rakton in person.
Sounds like fun.
Neither can I.
If Rakton's as smart as they say, this is far from over.
Let's not get too excited yet.
It always pays to be cautious. But our forces are leaving Rakton very few options.
You still have the A-77 operation to complete, so get to it. Garza out.
With more ground power to work with, we can finally start engaging Rakton's troops on every front.
If we keep up this momentum, we might turn this campaign completely around. Everything depends on the work of you and your team.
Havoc Squad is up to the task, General.
We're ready.
Good. We have a long road ahead of us.
We can turn this war around all by ourselves, General.
No sweat.
Bravado aside, it might still come to that.
Why does Havoc have to do all the work?
Haven't we done enough?
You don't. You only do the most important work.
Havoc Squad calling General Garza. A-77 was a trap.
We rescued Sergeant Jaxo, but all other prisoners were killed in action.
All of them? How did this happen, Major?
General Rakton lured us in, then his warships blew A-77 apart.
Rakton arranged everything.
If I'd moved faster, I might have gotten everyone out.
I was too slow.
You couldn't have known what was coming. Don't blame yourself.
Havoc should never have gone in with so little intel.
You didn't do your research!
No amount of intelligence gathering could have seen this coming.
It sounds like you were lucky to get anyone out at all. How did you and Jaxo manage it?
The only way to save Jaxo was to let the other prisoners die.
I had to choose.
Your mission was to save as many prisoners as possible. Jaxo is a valuable operator, but we needed those soldiers even more.
You made the wrong call, Major. But at least now we know how desperate General Rakton is to remove Havoc Squad from this war.
Get to your other assignments--ASAP. We need to keep the pressure on, especially now that we're three hundred soldiers short. Garza out.
Everyone ran for it. Jaxo made it out, the rest didn't.
[Lie] We were just lucky.
What a mess. I'm glad you and Jaxo made it out, at least.
Why so suspicious, General?
Is this an interrogation?
I only want all the facts.
Rakton must be getting desperate. He's realized the impact that Havoc is having on the war, and he wants it stopped at any cost.
We rescued most of the prisoners, but Sergeant Jaxo was killed in action.
Hmm. I'm sorry to hear about Jaxo, but it sounds like you were very fortunate to save as many as you did. What happened, exactly?
General Rakton had warships waiting to destroy A-77 and kill us all.
Rakton arranged everything.
Incredible. You did very well to escape a situation like that, Major.
If I hadn't been so slow, we might have gotten everyone out.
I should've moved faster.
Don't blame yourself. The situation wasn't your fault.
Our intel was limited--we never should've gone in.
You didn't do your research!
I doubt any amount of intelligence work would have warned us of this.
Tell me more about Sergeant Jaxo. Was she killed during the operation, or had she been recaptured before you arrived?
The only way to save the rest of the POWs was to let Jaxo die.
I had to choose.
I... see. That must have been very hard on you, but you made the right choice.
Jaxo sacrificed her life to save the others. She deserves a posthumous award.
She deserves a medal.
Understood. I'll get the documentation started immediately--it's the least we could do.
The sergeant died begging me to save her instead of the others.
Jaxo lost it.
Even the best soldiers can have a hard time facing the end, Major.
General Rakton is going to great lengths to remove Havoc from the war. We're clearly on the right track.
Let's keep the pressure on. Your next assignment is on a planet called Voss--I'm sending the coordinates now. Contact me as soon as you arrive. Garza out.
Before you proceed to your next objective, I need Havoc to take on a special mission--a prisoner-of-war rescue operation.
Bringing our people home is always a pleasure.
I'd be glad to.
Am I after a captured general or something?
Who's the prisoner?
You will be rescuing three hundred and fourteen men and women of various ranks.
My time would be better spent on the war effort.
We have other priorities.
Rescuing personnel from enemy captivity is a critical part of the war effort, Major.
The prisoners are being held on A-77, an Imperial detention center built inside the remains of an asteroid mining facility.
A Special Forces operator was recently captured and taken there--because of her, we learned A-77's location. You've worked with her before: Sergeant Jaxo.
Jaxo and I did two ops together.
Yes, I remember.
Correct. Here is her message from A-77:
I can't say I remember her, General.
Refresh my memory.
You knew her, sir. Very well.
Sergeant Jaxo worked with you here on Coruscant, then again on Nar Shaddaa. This is the message she broadcast from A-77:
Jaxo never wanted to follow procedures. Guess it caught up with her.
She was always careless.
It's possible. We never determined the full details of her capture. I'll forward her message from A-77:
Calling any Republic vessel or personnel. This is Ava Jaxo--sergeant, Republic Special Forces. I'm being held in an Imperial prison.
I've slipped out of my cell and hidden on the systems deck, but there are more than three hundred other soldiers being held here.
Any rescue teams, call me first--I'll do my best to muck up the security systems for you. Now get me out of here!
Just forward the coordinates and I'll move out, General.
I'll make it happen.
I've got to get her out of there.
That poor girl.
Jaxo is a professional. Focus on the mission as a whole, not just the details.
I can't imagine being trapped like that.
Must be rough.
Imperial prisons are renowned for their brutality. The faster we get our people out, the better.
What if the Imps are using Jaxo to lure us in?
It could be a trick.
Long-range scans match up with Jaxo's security codes. But it always pays to stay cautious.
A-77's coordinates are being forwarded to your navicomputer now. Contact Sergeant Jaxo once you're within range and proceed from there. Good luck.
Major, good. I was just reading over my reports from Belsavis. A largely successful operation--with the exception of Commander Gall.
Without Gall's leadership, Dagger Wing may never reach its previous potential. Why trade him for some crazed Sith Lord?
Commander Gall insisted that I capture Lord Ondorru to clear Dagger Wing's record.
Gall wanted it this way.
We could have caught Ondorru another time. Rescuing Gall was much more important.
I traded one man for a Sith who's killed thousands, General.
Ondorru was a priority target.
I'm not upset to have a man like Ondorru imprisoned. But Gall was the more important objective.
What's done is done, General.
Does it matter?
That's not an explanation, Major. Stick to your stated objectives next time.
Fortunately, Tobin Harlan has an exceptional combat record of his own. With time, he might lead the Daggers as well as Gall did.
Harlan is a good man--he knows what he's doing.
He will.
Good--Dagger Wing will be in good hands, then.
I don't know if Harlan's up to the job or not.
It's hard to say.
A unit is only as good as its leader. If Harlan can't cut it, the Daggers might not survive this conflict.
Our war is on the ground. Let the navy worry about Dagger Wing.
Who cares?
This is a war on many fronts. We need every branch operating at their peak if we're to have any hope of victory.
Bolstering our space forces was an important first step in our counteroffensive against General Rakton. But more remains to be done.
Overall, the counteroffensive against General Rakton is proceeding well. We've made great strides, but we aren't finished yet.
Major, good. I just finished reviewing the after-action reports from Belsavis--easily the best results we could've hoped for, given the circumstances.
Both Conrad Gall and Tobin Harlan recommended you be given a medal for your actions while rescuing Dagger Wing's pilots. Well done.
I'm always happy to do my part, General.
Thank you very much.
The bombing of Fest wasn't Dagger Wing's fault. Will the charges be cleared?
What about their records?
Time will tell. The situation is out of our hands.
It's nice to hear my hard work will be rewarded.
I can always use more medals.
Bear in mind, this was a very sensitive situation. Any awards will be a long time coming.
The counteroffensive against General Rakton is already off to a good start. Dagger Wing will only add to our forces' success.
Increased space superiority marks one more step in our counteroffensive against General Rakton. Your operations are giving our forces a decisive advantage.
You still have the A-77 situation to deal with, of course. Proceed there immediately. Garza out.
